answer:
<p>Anything you want to use for bitwise operations must be between 0x80000000 (-2147483648 or -2^31) and 0x7fffffff (2147483647 or 2^31 - 1).</p>

<p>The console will tell you that 0x80000000 equals +2147483648, but 0x80000000 &amp; 0x80000000 equals -2147483648.</p>

<p>In JavaScript the representation of numbers is <code>2^53 - 1</code>.</p>

<p><strong>However</strong>, <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Operators/Bitwise_Operators" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>Bitwise operation</code> are calculated on <code>32 bits ( 4 bytes )</code>, meaning if you exceed 32bits shifts you will start loosing bits.</a></p>
<p>In the Google Chrome built-in javascript, you can go to approximately 2^1024 before the number is called infinity.</p>
rows.title: What is JavaScript's highest integer value that a number can go to without losing precision?
rows.content: <p>Is this defined by the language? Is there a defined maximum? Is it different in different browsers?</p>
